title: 115_hr3074
content: The Act may be cited as the "Reclassification to Ensure Smarter and Equal Treatment Act of 2017" or the "RESET Act". It involves the reclassification of low-level felonies. In General, Part D of the Controlled Substances Act is amended to reduce penalties for certain offenses, including possession of a date rape drug. The Controlled Substances Act is amended to reduce penalties for drug offenses, with minimum imprisonment of 15 days to 3 years and fines starting at $2,500 for repeat offenders. The Controlled Substances Act is amended to reduce penalties for drug offenses, with minimum imprisonment of 90 days to 1 year and fines starting at $5,000. Provisions related to increased penalties for cocaine offenses involving cocaine base are repealed. SEC. 3. WEIGHING OF CONTROLLED SUBSTANCES MIXED WITH FOOD PRODUCTS. Amends the Controlled Substances Act to exclude the weight of food products when determining the weight of controlled substances mixed with them. SEC. 4. APPLICABILITY TO PENDING AND PAST CASES. This Act applies to offenses committed before enactment if no sentence has been imposed. For past cases, the sentencing court may reduce imprisonment terms for offenses affected by this Act, considering specified factors and policy statements. SEC. 5. EMERGENCY AUTHORITY FOR UNITED STATES SENTENCING COMMISSION. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend Federal sentencing guidelines for offenses affected by specific sections. SEC. 6. ESTABLISHMENT OF THE SAFE NEIGHBORHOODS AND SCHOOLS FUND. The "Safe Neighborhoods and Schools Fund" is established within the Department of Justice with continuous appropriation for its purposes. The Department of Justice will calculate savings from the implementation of the act annually. The Department of Justice will use actual data or best estimates for calculations, which will be final and not adjusted later. Results will be certified to Congress by August 1 each fiscal year. Funds will be transferred from the General Fund to the Safe Neighborhoods and Schools Fund before August 15 annually, exclusively for the purposes of the act. The Safe Neighborhoods and Schools Fund is allocated funds annually for specific purposes without fiscal year restrictions. By August 15 each year, the Controller distributes funds to the Department of Education for a grant program targeting truancy reduction and support for at-risk students. Additionally, a portion is allocated to the Federal Crime Victim program. The Safe Neighborhoods and Schools Fund allocates funds annually for specific purposes without fiscal year restrictions. A portion of the funds goes to the Federal Crime Victim Assistance Fund for trauma recovery centers to help victims of crime. Another portion goes to Federal Reentry/Drug Court programs for mental health and substance abuse treatment to reduce recidivism. The Safe Neighborhoods and Schools Fund allocates funds annually for specific purposes, including trauma recovery centers for crime victims and programs for mental health and substance abuse treatment to reduce recidivism. Fifty percent of the funds are allocated to the General Treasury to pay down the national debt. There is a limitation on administrative costs, with agencies not allowed to spend more than 5 percent of total funds received. The Department of Justice conducts audits every 2 years to ensure funds are used according to regulations. The Safe Neighborhoods and Schools Fund administers funds for various programs, including trauma recovery centers and mental health/substance abuse treatment. Costs incurred by the Department of Justice are deducted from the fund before disbursement. The funds are designated for expanding programs for public school pupils, victims of crime, and individuals in the criminal justice system. Agencies are prohibited from using the funds to replace existing state or local funds. Agencies are prohibited from providing programs or services above the funded level.
